hour.
By my troth agreed mother.
Nor does her wealth consist all in her flesh,
Though beauty be enough wealth for a woman,
She brings a Dowry of three hundred pound with her.
'sfoot that will serve till my Grandsire dies I warrant
you, he will drop away at fall of the leaf,
if ever he reach to all
Hollantide I will be hanged.
O yes son, he is a lusty old gentleman.
Ah pox, he is given to women; he keeps a quean at
this present.
Fie.
Do not tell my wife of it.
That were needless i'faith.
He makes a great feast upon the eleventh of this
month, tuesday next, and you shall see Players there, -- I have
one trick more to put upon him; my wife and yourself shall
go thither before as my guests, and prove his entertainment,
I will meet you there at night, the jest will be here, that feast
which he makes will, unknown to him, serve fitly for our wedding
dinner, we shall be royally furnished, and get some charges
by it.
An excellent course (i'faith) and a thrifty, why son,
methinks you begin to thrive before you are married.
We shall thrive one day wench, and clip enough?
Between our hopes there is but a Grandsires puff.
So girl, here was a bird well caught.
If ever, here: but what for his Grandsire,
it will scarce please
him well.
Who covets fruit, never cares from whence it fell,
Thou hast wedded youth and strength, and wealth will fall:
Last thou art made honest.
And that is worth them all.

stage.l: Enter busilie Sir Bounteous Progresse for the feast.

sp.l: Have a care blue coats; bestir yourself Master
Gumwater, cast an eye into the kitchen, overlook
the knaves a little, every
Jack has his friend today, this
cousin and that cousin puts in for a dish of meat, a man
knows not till he make a feast how many varlets he feeds,
acquaintances swarm in every corner,
like Flies at Bartholomew tide
that come up with drovers, 'sfoot I think they smell
my kitchen seven mile about master Shortrod and his sweet
bedfellow, you are very copiously welcome.
Sir, here is an especial dear friend of ours, we
were bold to make his way to your table.
Thanks for that boldness ever, good Master
Shortrod, is this your friend sir?
Both my wife's friend and mine sir.
Why then compendiously sir, -- you are welcome.
In Octavo I thank you sir.
Excellently retorted i'faith, he is welcome for his wit;
I have my sorts of salutes, and know how to place them Courtly;
walk in sweet gentlemen, walk in, there is a good fire in the
Hall, you shall have my sweet company instantly.
Aye good sir Bounteous
You shall indeed gentlemen; how now, what
news brings thee in stumbling now?
There are certain Players come to town sir, and desire
to interlude before your worship.
Players? by the mass they are welcome, they will grace
my entertainment well, but for certain players there thou liest
boy; they were never more
uncertain in their lives, now up and
now down, they know nor when to play, where to play, nor
what to play, not when to play for fearful fools, where to play
for Puritan fools, nor what to play for critical fools -- go
call them in, -- how fitly the whoresons come upon the feast, troth I
was e'en wishing for them, -- o welcome, welcome my friends.
The month of May delights not in her flowers,
More than we joy in that sweet sight of yours.
Well acted on my credit, I perceive he is your best
Actor.
He has greatest share sir; and may live of himself sir.
What what? put on your hat sir, pray put on; go to,
wealth must be respected let those that have least feathers stand
bare; and whose men are you I pray? nay keep on your hat still.
We serve my Lord Owemuch sir.
My Lord Owemuch, by my troth the welcomest men alive
give me all your hands at once, that honourable gentleman? he
lay at my house in a robbery once, and took all quietly, went
away cheerfully. I made a very good feast for him;
I never saw
a man of honour bear things bravelier away, serve my Lord Owemuch?
welcome i'faith: some Bastard for my Lords Players, --
where be you boys?
Thy come along with the Waggon sir.
Good, good, and which is your Politician amongst
you? now i'faith he that works out Restraints, makes
best legs at Court, and has a suit made of purpose, for the
companies business, which is he, come, be not afraid of him.
I am he sir.
Art thou he? give me thy hand, hark in thine
ear, thou rollest too fast to gather so much moss as thy fellow
there, champ upon that, ah, and what play shall we have
my masters?
A pleasant witty Comedy sir.
Aye, aye, aye, a Comedy in any case that I and my guests
may laugh a little, what is the name of it?
It is called the Slip.
The Slip? By my troth a pretty name, and a glib
one: go all and slip into it, as fast as you can, cover a table for
the players. First take heed of a Lurcher, he cuts deep, here
will eat up all from you. Some Sherry for my Lords players
there. Sirrah, why this will be a True feast, a right Mitre supper,
a play and all, more lights. -- I called for light, here come in
two are light enough for
a whole house i'faith. Dare the
thief look me in the face? O impudent times! go to, dissemble
it.
Bless you sir Bounteous.
O welcome, welcome, Thief, Quean, and Bawd,
welcome all three.
Nay here is but two of us sir.
On my troth, I took her for a couple, I would have
sworn there had been two faces there.
Not all under one hood sir.
Yes faith would I, to see mine eyes bear double.
I will make it hold sir, my daughter is a couple,
She was married yesterday.
Buzz.
Nay to no buzzard neither, a right Hawk
When ever you know him.
Away, he cannot be but a Rascal, walk in, walk
in, bold guests, that come unsent for -- post, I perceive how
my Jewels went now, to grace her marriage.
Would you wish me sir?
Ay, how happed it wench, you put the slip upon me,
Not three nights since? I name it gently to you,
I term it neither Pilfer, Cheat, nor Shark.
You are past my reach.
I am old and past your reach, very good; but you
will not deny this I trust.
With a safe conscience, sir.
Ye? give me thy hand, fare thee well, I have done
with her.
Give me your hand, sir, you never yet begun with
me.
Whew, whew? O audacious age,
She denies me and all, when on her fingers,
I spied the Ruby sir, that does betray her,
And blushes for her fact, well there is a time for it,
For all is too little now for entertainment.
Feast, mirth, aye harmony, and the play to boot
A Jovial Season. How now, are you ready?
Even upon readiness sir.
Keep you your hat on.
I have a suit to your worship.
O cry you mercy, then you must stand bare.
We could do all to the life of action sir, both for the
credit of your worships house, and the grace of our Comedy.
Gods me, what else sir?
And for some defects (as the custom is) we would be
bold to require your worships assistance.
Why with all my heart, what is it you want? speak.
One is a chain for a Justices hat sir.
Why here, here, here, here whoreson, will this serve
your turn?
What else lack you?
We should use a ring with a stone in it.
Nay whoop, I have given too many rings already,
talk no more of rings I pray you, here, here, here, make this
Jewel serve for once.
O this will serve sir.
What have you all now?
All now sir -- only time
is brought in the middle of the
play, and I would desire your worships watch time.
My watch, with all my heart, only give time a
charge that he be not fiddling with it.
You shall never see that sir.
Well now you are furnished sir, make haste away.
Even as fast as I can sir, --
I will set my fellows going first,
they must have time and leisure, or they are dull else.
I will stay and speak a prologue, yet overtake them, I cannot have
conscience i'faith to go away and speak
never a word to them,
my Grandsire has given me three shares here, sure I will do somewhat
for them.

stage.l: Enter Sir Bounteous and all the Guests.

sp.l: More lights, more stools, sit sir, the play begins.
Have you players here Sir Bounteous?
We have them for you sir, fine nimble Comedians,
proper actors most of them.
Whose men I pray you sir?
O there is their credit sir, they serve an honourable
popular Gentleman, yclept my Lord Ow-much.
My Lord Ow-much, he was in Ireland lately.
O you never knew any of the name but were great
travellers,
How is the Comedy called, Sir Bounteous?
Marry sir, the Slip.
The Slip?
Aye, and here the prologue begins to slip in upon us.
It is so indeed Sir Boun.
We sing of wandering Knights, what them betide,
Who nor in one place, nor one shape abide,
They are here now, and anon no scouts can reach them
Being every man well horsed like a bold Beecham,
The Play which we present, no fault shall meet
But one, you will say it is short, we will say it is sweet:
It is given much to dumb shows, which some praise,
And like the Term, delights much in delays.
So to conclude, and give the name her due,
The play being called the Slip, I vanish too.
Excellently well acted and a nimble conceit.
The Prologue is pretty i'faith.
And went off well.
Aye that is the grace of all, when they go away well, ah --
On my troth if I were not married, I could find in my
Heart to fall in love with that Player now, and send for him to
a supper; I know some in the town that have done as much and
there took such a good conceit of their parts into the twopenny
room, that the Actors have been found in the morning in
a less compass than their Stage, though it were
never so full of gentlemen.
But, passion of me, where be these knaves, will they
not come away, methinks they stay very long.
O you must bear a little sir, they have many
shifts to run into.
Shifts call you them, they are horrible long things.
A pox of such fortune the plot is betrayed:
All will come out, yonder they come taken upon suspicion,
and brought back by a Constable, I was accursed to hold society
with such Coxcombs, what is to be done? I shall be
shamed forever, my wife here and all, ah pox -- by light happily
thought upon, the chain? Invention stick to me this once,
and fail me ever hereafter: so, so, --
Life I say, where be these Players, o are you come,
troth it is time, I was e'en sending for you.
How moodily he walks, what plays he trow?
A, Justice upon my credit, I know by the chain there.
Unfortunate Justice.
Ah. -- ah -- ah
In thy kin unfortunate,
Here comes thy Nephew now upon suspicion,
Brought by a Constable before thee, his vild associates with him,
But so disguised, none knows him but myself,
Twice have I set him free from officers fangs,
And for his sake, his fellows: let him look to it:
My conscience will permit but one wink more.
Ye shall we take Justice winking.
For this time I have bethought a means to work thy
freedom, though hazarding myself; should the Law seize him,
Being kin to me, it would blemish much my name, No;
I would rather lean to danger, than to shame.
A very explete Justice.
Thank you good neighbours, let me alone with them now.
'sfoot who is yonder?
Dare he sit there?
Follywit.
-- Captaine -- puh --
How now Constable what news with thee?
May it please your worship sir, -- here a company of
auspicious fellows.
To me? puh -- turn to the Justice you whoreson hobby-horse,
this is some new player now, they put all their fools
to the Constables part still.
What is the matter Constable, what is the matter?
I have nothing to say to your worship -- they were all
riding on horseback if it please your worship
Yet again; a pox
of all Asses still, they could not ride
a foot unless it were in a bawdy house.
The Ostler told me they were all unstable fellows sir.
Why sure the fellow is drunk.
We spied that weakness in him long ago sir, your
worship must bear with him, the man
is much overseen, only
in respect of his office we obeyed him, both to appear conformable
to law, and clear of all offence: for I protest sir,
he found us but on horse back:
What he did?
As I have a soul, that is all, and all he can lay to us.
i'faith, you were not riding away then.
'sfoot, being on horseback sir, that must needs follow.
Why true sir.
Well said Justice, he helps his kinsman well.
Why Sirrah, do you use to bring Gentlemen before
us for riding away, what will you have them stand still when
they are up, like Smug upon the white horse yonder? are your wits
steeped? I will make you an example for all dizzy Constables,
how they abuse justice, here bind him to this chair.
Ha, bind him ho?
If you want cords, use garters.
Help, help, Gentlemen.
As fast as we can sir.
Thieves, thieves.
A gag will help all this, keep less noise you knave.
O help, rescue the Constable -- o, O.
Ho, ho, ho, ho.
Why la you who lets you now?
You may ride quietly, I will see you too,
Take horse myself. I have nothing else to do.
Ha, ha ha, by my troth the maddest piece of Justice
gentlemen, that ever was committed.
I will be sworn for the madness of it sir.
I am deceived, if this prove not a merry Comedy
and a witty.
Alas poor Constable, his mouth is open, and
never a wise word.
Faith he speaks now e'en as many as he has done,
He seems wisest when he gapes and says nothing, ha, ha; --
he turns and tells his tale to me like an ass, what have I to do
with their riding away, they may ride for me, thou whoreson
Coxcomb thou: nay thou art well enough served i'faith.
But what follows all this while sir; methinks
some should pass by before this time, and pity the Constable.
by the mass and you say true sir, -- go sirrah, step
in, I think they have forgot themselves, call the knaves away
they are in a wood I believe --
Aye, aye, aye.
Hark, the Constable says aye, they are in a wood, --
ha, ha --
He thinks long of the time sir Bounteous.
How now? when come they?
Alas if it please your worship, there is not one of them
to be found sir.
How?
What says the fellow?
Neither horse nor man sir.
Body of me thou liest.
Not a hair of either sir.
How now sir Bounteous.
Cheated and defeated, ungag that rascal, I will
hang him for his fellows, I will make him bring them out.
Did not I tell your worship this before, brought them
before you for suspected persons, stayed them at towns end upon
warning given, made signs that my very jaw bone aches,
your worship would not hear me, called me Ass, saving your
worships presence laughed at me.
Ha?
I begin to taste it.
Give me leave, give me leave, why art not thou the
Constable in the Comedy?
In the Comedy? why I am the constable in the common
wealth sir.
I am gulled i'faith, I am gulled, when wast thou chose?
On thursday last sir.
A pox go with it, there it goes.
I seldom heard Jest match it.
Nor I i'faith.
Gentlemen shall I entreat a courtesy?
What is it sir?
Do not laugh at me seven year hence.
We should betray and laugh at
our own folly
then, for of my troth none here but was deceived in it.
Faith that is some comfort yet, ha, ha, it was featly
carried, troth I commend their wits, before our faces, make
us asses while we sit still,
and only laugh at ourselves.
Faith they were some counterfeit rogues sir.
Why they confess so much themselves, they said
they would play the slip, they should be men of their words, I hope
the Justice will have more conscience i'faith, then to carry away
a chain of a hundred mark of that fashion.
What sir?
Aye by my troth sir, besides a jewel, and a jewels fellow,
a good fair watch that hung about my neck sir.
'sfoot what did you mean sir?
Methinks my Lord Owemuches players should
not scorn me so i'faith they
will come and bring all again I
know, push they will i'faith, but a jest certainly.

stage.l: Enter Follywit in his owne shape, and all the rest.

sp.l: Pray Grandsire give me your blessing?
Who? Son Folliwit?
This shows like kneeling after the play, I praying
for my Lord Owemuch and his good Countess, our honourable
Lady and Mistress.
Rise richer by a blessing, thou art welcome.
Thanks good grandsire, I was bold to bring those
gentlemen my friends.
They are all welcome, salute you that side, and I will welcome
this side. Sir to begin with you.
Master Follywit.
I am glad it is our fortune so happily to meet sir.
Nay then you know me not sir.
Sweet Mistress Harebraine.
You cannot be too bold sir.
Our marriage known?
Not a word yet.
The better.
Faith son would you had come sooner with these
gentlemen.
Why Grandsire?
We had a play here.
A play sir, no.
Yes faith, a pox on the Author.
Bless us all, why were they such vild ones sir?
I am sure villainous ones sir.
Some raw simple fools.
Nay by the mass these were enough for thievish
knaves.
What sir?
Which way came you gentlemen, you could not
choose but meet them.
We met a company with hampers after them.
O those were they, those were they, a pox hamper
them.
Bless us all again.
They have hampered me finely sirrah.
How sir.
How sir, I lent the rascals properties to furnish
out their play, a chain, a jewel, and a watch, and they watched
their time, and rid quite away with them.
Are they such creatures.
Hark, hark gentlemen, by this light the
watch rings alarum in his pocket, there is my watch come again,
or the very Cousin German to it, whose is it, whose is it? by the
mass it is he, hast thou one son? prithee bestow it upon thy
Grandsire, I now look for mine again
i'faith, nay come with a
good will or not at all, I will give thee a better thing a piece, a
piece gentlemen.
Great or small,
At once I have drawn chain, jewel, watch and all.
By my faith you have a fortunate hand sir.
Nay all to come at once.
A vengeance of this foolery.
Have I scaped the Constable to be brought in by the
watch?
O destiny, have I married a Thief mother?
Comfort thyself, thou art before hand with him
daughter.
Why son, why gentlemen, how long have you been
my Lord Ow-much his servants i'faith?
Faith Grandsire, shall I be true to you?
I think it is time, thou hast been a thief already.
I knowing the day of your feast, and the natural inclination
you have to pleasure and pastime, presumed upon your
patience for a jest as well to prolong your days as --
Whoop, why then you took my chain along
with you to prolong my days did you?
Not so neither sir and that you may be seriously assured
of my hereafter stableness of life, I have took another course.
What?
Took a wife.
A wife? 'sfoot, what is she for a fool would marry
thee a madman? when was the wedding kept in Bedlam?
She is both a gentlewoman and a virgin.
Stop there, stop there, would I might see her?
You have your wish, she is here.
Ah, ha, ha, ha, this makes amends for all.
How now?
Captain do you hear? is she your wife in earnest?
How then?
Nothing but pity you sir.
Speak son is it true?
Can you gull us, and let a quean gull you.
Ha.
What I have been is past, be that forgiven,
And have a soul true both to thee and heaven.
Is it come about, tricks are repaid I see.
The best is sirrah you pledge none but me
And since I drink the top, take her and hark,
I spice the bottom with a thousand mark.
By my troth, she is as good a cup of Nectar as any
Bachelor needs to sip at.
Tut give me gold, it makes amends for vice,
Maids without coin, are caudles without spice.
Come gentlemen to the feast, let not time waste,
We have pleased our ear, now let us please our taste
Who lives by cunning mark it, his fates cast,
When he has gulled all, then is himself the last.
